Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Calder Summer Undergraduate Research (CSUR) Program in Conservation and Urban Ecology
Award.AbstractNarration: Fordham University and the Louis Calder Center - Biological Field Station have been awarded funding to support 10 students each summer in a 12-week research program in ecology and conservation biology, with a strong emphasis on effects of urbanization. Students will collaborate with mentors to design research projects that test critical questions, and lead to success in graduate school and employment in growing areas of ecology and environmental sciences. The goal is to help students become leaders of their research projects and in the years to come, leaders in science and environmental stewardship. Students who have limited opportunities to conduct ecological research will be provided training and research opportunities within a field station setting, and free on-site housing, travel support and ready access to research mentors with expertise ranging from population genetics to ecosystem processes. Students can address critical conservation issues within an urban-suburban landscape, and examine the link between scientific research and benefits to society. The proximity of the field station to New York City also offers students a sharp focus on human impacts to biological systems. Links with scientists at the Wildlife Conservation Society, Bronx Zoo and New York Botanical Garden will offer a broad array of research opportunities. Students will be guided to formulate and defend their hypotheses, and design and complete their research within the 12-week period. Students will disseminate their findings in oral and poster presentations at scientific conferences, in undergraduate theses, and in peer-reviewed publications. The CSUR-REU program targets highly motivated students interested in pursuing a career in ecology and conservation biology. Program success will be assessed using the NSF BIO-REU common assessment tool, and an anonymous Students' Evaluation of Educational Quality (SEEQ) form developed at Fordham. Students from institutions with limited opportunities for research, urban backgrounds, or from groups under-represented in science are especially encouraged to apply. Students interested in applying can obtain more information by visiting the website www.fordham.edu/REUatCalder, or contacting REUatCalder@fordham.edu or 914-273-3078 ext. 27.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report – NSF REU #1063076

Intellectual Merit

The Calder Summer Undergraduate Research (CSUR) program has as its central goal to provide students who have limited opportunities to conduct ecological research, challenging and meaningful training and research opportunities “on the spot”, in a biological field station setting.  Each student developed their ideas with mentors prior to arriving at the station. On arrival, each student formulated a research plan, which was presented to the group in the form of a “chalk-talk” proposal.  From this beginning, students developed research projects, and tested a wide range of ecological questions the complex nature of human – environment interactions.  

Here are examples of discoveries resulting from REU students’ research:

- DNA analyses of red oak trees in the NYC region indicate a reduction in alleles among younger trees, suggesting a reduction in genetic diversity over time.

- Catnip oil shows promise as a botanical repellent of blacklegged ticks, the vector of Lyme disease.

- A reduction in forested corridors along rivers reduces the capacity of stream microbes to absorb phosphorus, an important pollutant.

- Several invasive mosquito species from Asia, some of which are capable of transmitting the West Nile virus, may be outcompeting native species in certain habitats.

- Populations of coyotes in NYC appear to be genetically distinct from their suburban or non-urban cousins.

- Rooted aquatic plants may work to reduce the effects of eutrophication in a suburban lake that suffers from undesirable algal blooms.

- Bats are relatively abundant and moderately diverse in urban environments, including in the Bronx, NY, and are active in both summer and winter months.

- Populations of eastern box turtles are declining due to habitat loss from urbanization, but relocation methods may be a successful conservation management strategy.

- Extreme rainfall events, which are increasing in frequency, influence the flow of nutrients from watersheds into urban rivers.

- Biodiversity of carrion beetles does not vary significantly along an urban-rural gradient in the NYC region.

Upon completion, students continue their scientific experiences. Over the 5-year period (3 REU summer programs), students attended regional, national, and international conferences to present their findings. REU students presented at least 23 talks or posters at these forums. We also disseminated results in the form of scientific publications (current count 8 peer-reviewed publications, others in prep), web postings and Twitter feeds. We are continuing to submit additional papers for publication in peer-reviewed scientific journals, with REU students as co-authors.

 

Broader Impacts

 

Our REU program had as one of its aims to demonstrate the importance of ecological science in the urban - suburban world.  All student projects were grounded in solid scientific principles, and aimed to address environmental problems that face society. We provided students with hands-on experiences to address current challenges that have resulted from human-environment interactions, such as environmental change, ecology of vector borne diseases, loss of biodiversity, understanding urban wildlife, and restoring damaged ecosystems.

 

From the perspective of broadening participation in the sciences, our program situated at a biological field station, provided the resources to assist student research and to remove barriers to individuals who might not otherwise participate directly in scientific research.  Students had use of research vehicles, a wide array of research equipment, access to university wi-fi and library resources, and free on-site housing.  A total of 32 students participated over the course of the grant. Of these, 23 were women (72%), 13 (41%) were students from small colleges, and 15 (47%) were self-identified as members of groups under-represented in the sciences, as designated by the NSF.

 

We continue to follow up on each student's academic achievements and career direction, and offer advice on their career path in subsequent years. All participants have graduated (one will graduate in 2017) with a B.S. or B.A. in relevant fields including Biological Sciences, Environmental Science / Studies, Wildlife Biology, Agricultural Science, Environmental Health Science, Forensic Science & Molecular Biology, Forestry, Natural Sciences, and Marine Biology. Since graduating, nearly all REU fellows (94%) have pursued careers in a science-related field or have continued their education in graduate school.
